text:
(3).

A general view northwest from the Brooklyn Bridge, and showing the Cherry Hill waterfront, between James Slip (left) and Market Slip (right, not shown). Just beyond, in the center of view is the Bowery and Chatham Square area. The North (Hudson) River, and the Jersey Shore line appear across the top of the view. This waterfront section comprises Piers (old) Nos. 31 (extreme left) to 36, and are occupied respectively by the Ferry to Long Island City (Pier 31, James Slip), Bridge Street Ferry (Pier 32), Philadelphia and New York S.S. Co., or the Clyde Line from Philadelphia (Piers 33 and 34), the Catherine Street Ferry to Brooklyn, (foot of Catherine Slip), Bridgeport Line S.S. (Pier 35), and the Central Vermont R.R. and S.S. Line (Pier 36). Distinctly shown at the rear of the Catherine Street Ferry, is the Catherine Market, with Van Dyke's Hotel (N.E. corner of South Street), and Brook's Bros., Clothiers (N.E. corner of Cherry Street), and the Lorillard House (N.W. corner of South Street), surrounding same.

About 1870- 1875.

Brown Brothers.

Published in the American on December 1908, and the New York Times of October 20, 1912.
title: General view - Manhattan - [View of Lower Manhattan from Brooklyn Bridge.]

text:
(1)
Catherine Slip, west side, north from South, to but not including Water Streets. Buildings on the left are Nos. 202 to 195 South Street and are on the north side, from Catherine Slip to Oliver Street; the corner building being No. 202. Adjoining this corner building is No. 24-22 Catherine Slip (the two 4-story buildings) occupied by the Catherine Mission. The building on the extreme right (No. 18 Catherine Slip) is the Italian Church and adjoins an empty lot directly at the S,W. corner of Water Street. September 24, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
A similar view slightly northward, showing a one story garage at the S.W. corner of Water Street. Shown on the right are buildings on Water Street, at and adjoining the N.W. corner of Catherine Slip. May 1924.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

title: Manhattan: Catherine Slip - South Street

text:
(1) Catherine Slip, east side, north from South, to, but not including Cherry Streets, showing (foreground), No. 27, at the N.E. corner of South Street. It is only remaining tenement on the block. Also shown, overpowering the little house, is the west wall of the Hearst Publications Building. September 7, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) A detail of the same, showing a more prominent view of No. 27. September 7, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Catherine Slip - South Street

title: Manhattan: Catherine Slip - South Street

text:
210
South Street, north side, east from and including Catherine Slip, showing (prominently) the New York American (Hearst Publications) Building, from Catherine to Market Slips. The little 4-story house shown clustered against the New York American Building, is No. 27 Catherine Slip, at the N.E. corner of South Street, and is the only remaining tenement on that entire block. A portion of the Manhattan Bridge is visible in the background.
June 22, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

The same, showing an exclusive view of the Hearst Publication Building, and its "little neighbor".
May 3, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: South Street - Catherine Slip

title: Manhattan: South Street - Catherine Slip

text:
South Street, west from Catherine Slip to Roosevelt Street; at which point it makes a sharp turn southward. Also shown, is a portion of the Brooklyn Bridge. Across same (left to right), are the Farmer's Loan and Trust Co., No. 60 Wall Street Tower and the Bank of Manhattan Co.

P. L. Sperr.

The same, from another angle. Also shown, is Catherine Slip, at the N.W. corner of South Street (used as an automobile parking space), and Nos. 20 and 18. In the background are visible (left), the Woolworth Building and (right), the tower of the Municipal Building.

June 22, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

A portion of the same, showing only Nos. 199, 198 and 197 South Street (left). Also shown, is a more extensive view on Catherine Slip to Water Street.

June 22, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

According to the New York Times of December 21, 1937, the clearance at the aforementioned corner will be improved with a one story structure, and used as a gasoline station.
